item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2009/09/03/showing-your-last-tweet-with-javascript/#comment-3039">Austin</a>.
In defense of my jQuery laziness http://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.3.2/jquery.min.js only transmits 19kb over the wire :-)
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Austin.

In defense of my jQuery laziness http://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.3.2/jquery.min.js only transmits 19kb over the wire üôÇ

item.title: By: Austin
item.dc:creator: Austin
item.content:encoded:
It’s a great idea and would be even better by dropping jQuery’s 57kb of bloat.

Assign the tweet wrapper element to a variable:

var lastTweet = document.getElementById('last_tweet');

Then you can replace

$('#last_tweet').html(

with

lastTweet.innerHTML =

and

$('#last_tweet').addClass('last_tweet_box');

with

lastTweet.className = 'last_tweet_box';

It’s guaranteed to be faster, too!

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2009/09/03/showing-your-last-tweet-with-javascript/#comment-3037">Bouke</a>.
True, there are definitely other ways to do this.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Bouke.

True, there are definitely other ways to do this.

item.title: By: Bouke
item.dc:creator: Bouke
item.content:encoded:
Nice example, but you could make better use of JQuery by using an AJAX-call, like this:


$.ajax({
url: "http://twitter.com/statuses/user_timeline/josephscott.json",
data: { count: 1 },
dataType: "jsonp",
success: twitter_callback_function
});
